plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to publication of the First Half Year 2011 Financial Account of EDF Group. I will now – I'll start with summarizing the major facts of the half year. Then, of course, I will come back. On our ambition 2020 that I've already mentioned before, some of you during the shareholders general meeting, after which Thomas Piquemal will present the details of the figures for the half year and the outlook for 2011, and more generally the outlook for our ambition until 2015.

Let's start with the financial result of the first half year of 2011. Around – We won't teach you anything if I say that the contest was particularly challenging, complex, uncertain with of course the Fukushima accident that released with much acuteness and on the global scale the choice of future energy policies. A number of other major highlights of market high industry, particularly in France as well as elsewhere. And we'll be discussing that.

Let's start with performance in the first half year, performance that can be regarded as highly positive in spite of the troubled environment. First, with the satisfaction is an improvement of our income, improvement that comes essentially from operation improvement.

Organic growth of 6.2% EBITDA, nearly 40% improved EBIT. Improvement found in the strong growth of the net income multiplied by 2.4 in particular, for the attributable net income and +12.5% for our net income from current operation.

Another important point to highlight is that we have recovered some leeway margins from maneuver by improving our net debt and debt net over EBITDA ratio, which as you see today, is around two. And that debt is being covered by 2 years of EBITDA, meaning that, EDF's balance sheet is probably one of the soundest in our industry.

We're actually the only company in the sector to have an increase in our rating which is now up to AA- by Standard & Poor's. We've played a major role, as you know, and we continue to play a major role in the nuclear sector; which is strategic for economy, as was reminded last Monday when we set-up the nuclear strategic committee for the nuclear industry. Very solid results.
In spite of uncertainties, we have not moved off course from our strategic ambition or our priorities, as tested by these highlights of the first half year of 2011.
Among these highlights, let's start with the improved operational performance. That was our key priority, to improve our output efficiency and it was the pre-requisite for any future growth.

We've reached this target with an excellent performance of nuclear output, plus 7.7% in France and in the U.K. was nearly 25% increase in the output efficiency. Although in the previous fiscal year, we had a maintenance shutdown in one of our power plants.

However, the performance of the nuclear fleets, both in France and the U.K., has reached record high this – in this first half year. And we remind you as well that in the U.K. last week, 18th of July, the U.K. government confirmed it's nuclear – energy choices by approving nuclear developments.

In fact, I'll remind you that the level of the nuclear output has reached 43.9 terawatt hour, a level unprecedented in the history of EDF. We were also able to keep up our targets, particularly thanks to a very low number of – unplanned outages. Down 371 days in the semester, and so, very significant progress in reducing the number of unplanned outages.

This results from major investments in maintenance, in particularly, to replace major components in our power plants, replacement that is accelerating. Thus, the nuclear efficiency, which is significantly higher than it was in last year and even above our expectation, had two positive effects. First of all, we were able to review upwards our annual targets for the year 2011 within a range of 411 to 418 terawatt hour, instead of the 408 to 450 in initially planned.

Second effect was to offset highly deteriorated climate conditions that impacted the hydro-power output. This year the lack of rainfall and snowfall have actually caused approximately 35% decrease in the water flows. To this excellent performance of the French nuclear and U.K. nuclear fleet, we can also add a significant decrease in the average power cuts down 16 minutes versus 2011. So this shows a test to the real progress I have made in terms of operations.

The announcement last year of the Flamanville – the new construction schedule for Flamanville, goes in the same direction and fits into the rationale of sharing information, of course that is fully transparent. The first semester 2011 was highlighted by two key events. First of all, we have strengthened our position in renewable, with the decision of taking over the EDF Energies Nouvelles. We now own 96.71% of EDF EN shares and, after the following process to buyback the remaining share, we will own 100%.

The second highlight is the decision of the ARENH price, that was set at €42, as of January, 2012. The NOME Law came into effect on the 1st of July, 2011, and the CRE regulator has already mentioned that our competitors have been demanding 61 terawatt hour. I remind you that the total amount that has been approved by EDF is 100 terawatt hour. This leads me to deduce that those who were claiming that the ARENH price were not – was not advantageous, actually are finding it quite sufficient.

So, in that solid semester with the committing and positive decisions for EDF enabled us to reassert our ambitions for organic growth. So, priority to profitable growth this may not be very original, but that is the meaning that we want to give to the Group strategy. As in introduction, in this first half year was highlighted by the events at Fukushima, as well as the contrasted, and sometimes drastic, reactions that led to some governmental decisions in Europe and elsewhere.

Let me add that the nuclear – nuclear power has its right – full-fledged right for base in the future energy mix. Neither the U.S. nor China nor Russia or the U.K. are even considering doing away with nuclear power. Not any more than South Africa, India and many other countries. I told you earlier that the British government adopted two weeks ago the approval of building new power plants, nuclear power plant. And the reform of the electricity market actually confirms the implementation of favorable conditions to invest in carbon-free energies, including nuclear power.

And this illustrates another dimension of the energy mix expansion, different from what was chosen by country East of France. France has opted for nuclear power. And my conviction, I repeat, is that nuclear power is a carbon-free energy and safe energy provided that we devoted the necessary investment and it is interested to comprehensive operators. Beyond this performance, we are fully aware of our strong responsibility as an operator, of course. A role that places us on the forefront, as you know, in the nuclear sector; and this is probably the very first lesson to be learned from Fukushima.

As you know that – you know the safety quarter is part of EDF's DNA and it's reflected in an ongoing approach to improve a safety end performance of our fleet. Hence, the necessary investment in maintenance to – in proper operation of the powers – of the power plant and extension of their life span. In 2010, in France, we devoted 1.7 – excuse me, 1.5 billion in – let me repeat, in 2009, 1.5 billion. We devoted in 2010, 1.7 billion will be invested for maintenance and should reach – should exceed that by 2015.

Of course our ambition is not committed to nuclear only. At the latest shareholders assembly, last May, I presented the Group's strategic orientations; orientations that intend to position EDF as a global electricity operator, operating in all of its businesses with one goal: to be the global leader of carbon-free electricity. By 2020, I'd like to renew our – restate our ambition to have an electricity generation fleet with 75% carbon-free outputs. We also intend to sustain and continue our leadership. To this purpose, EDF can and must propose its scales and expertise to support other operators in countries, particularly in developing a safer nuclear power.

In renewable energies, our commitment is clearly stated by our takeover of EDF EN. And, we are now fully in charge to develop projects and draw the benefits in line with our investments. Our commitment in renewables will also involve our determination and our commercial ability to win future tenders in hydro-power concessions in France, of course, as well as in other countries worldwide.

Lastly, within this energy mix, we are not neglecting nuclear – excuse me, thermal power. Gas and Coal remain important components in the global energy mix. It is up to us, to how country is developed technologies that are more modern, more environmentally friendly; as we will be doing in Poland by developing clean coal with super critical coal or in Asia with combined cycle gas turbines.

As you see, our expertise, which is recognized on a global level – determinates our growth ambitions provided, of course that this growth must be profitable. To do so, we need to have higher demand in terms of return on investments. Thomas would be speaking about that. We review the CapEx criteria to ensure that all projects will create value. And still in the perspective of optimizing the profitability of higher growth, we've also redefined our development revenues.
This involves, first of all, clarifying our international partnerships. We've gone through several complex and sometimes constraining situations.

In the U.S., in particular, we've put an end to the threat of the put that could have been exercised by Constellation that could've cost us up to $2 billion. In Germany, we exited from EnBW at the time where the context was becoming unfavorable. Initially, the decision may have been surprising, but the recent political choices in Germany probably now proves us right.

With that, regarding Edison Italy, as you know, our shareholders agreement has been extended up to the 15th of September and we've been working with A2A to find a solution and comfort Edison's position as the second electricity operator in Italy. Now that these situations are being clarified or are being clarified along with the takeover of EDF NE now confers us a full mastery over our strategy to keep going forward.

So, a global benchmark of electricity with an ambition consistent with the group's identity. This ambition is actually facilitated by EDF's integrated model, vertical integration of all businesses, from down-streams to up-streams, from design and build all the way to operation and management of services. Within all of these businesses, EDF is and should and must remain a global reference. So, vertical integration of our businesses, but an open architecture worldwide, authorizing all forms of alliances, partnerships, contracts, managements in France and elsewhere. The only keyword is to capture growth where it is.

And we will use our key assets, mainly the diversity of our skills in response to the diverse situations and expectations of our clients everywhere across the world, expertise in hydro-power engineering, fossil fuel power plants, design and operation of networks, scales and expertise in trading and services.

Last June 17th, EDF signed a partnership agreement with MRSK, the Russian electricity distributor, relative to the maintenance and quality of the distribution created in Russia. In this country, we've also initiated collaboration with Gazprom and Rosatom in complimentary areas.
While our domestic playing field is Europe, we'll also intend to develop in countries where we already enjoy historical partnerships and very strong competence. In China, for instance,
we've been working for the past 35 years with the CGNPC or the U.S. or in South Africa with ESKOM.

Our target is to boost our presence in high-growth countries with considerable energy requirements, Poland, Turkey or Brazil among many others. In Brazil, in particular, we want to be present there and last June we inaugurated the very first solar power plant in the state of Rio de Janeiro at the power plant of UTE Norte Fluminense. To sum it up, EDF Group every day is more open to the world, with an output capacity that has grown 50% internationally.

Being a benchmark electricity operator means also anticipate the future in preparing for the challenges of the 22nd century in the world that will be faced with major issues of climate warming, security of supply or doubled global demand for electricity by 2015. And to this purpose, and this is another asset we enjoy perhaps to let you know, that we will continue to strengthen innovation in R&D, which have always been a key strength for EDF and that will continue to boost out our technology potential over the coming years.

2,000 engineers and technicians have already been mobilized to develop the group's ability to anticipate and develop all of these businesses. Material ageing, CO2 capture and storage, solar photovoltaic, new generation, offshore wind, concentration solar power and marine turbines are as many areas of major potential for the future where we intend to develop.

Efforts in R&D will also include efforts in networks, energy demand to make sure that electricity becomes the energy of the sustainable city. Among other examples is a development of smart grids and smart systems, including smart meters, like the Linky meter experimented successfully by ERDF, low-energy buildings, reasonable price for smart buildings, innovative usage of electricity for transport comfort of industry.

This is reason we inaugurated last June the new R&D center of the group in Beijing dedicated to CO2 capture and storage and to smart grids, two sectors that represent a major challenge for China in the major challenge of the sustainable city. Anticipating the future for EDFR also will guarantee that the skills and expertise will be kept within the company, we are all mobilized to meet this major challenge and make sure that EDF can not only renew its skills and expertise but also to develop these skills to respond to our future growth.

So, I briefly summarized the semester for you, in which we've seen a lot of events and progress for our group. Within 18 months of presence together with my team we have solved four key challenges on the mid-term for the group. First of all, operational performance, we've been increased our nuclear output in France and in the U.K. among others, secondly, defense of our interest under the new NOME Law in France and defense of our interest everywhere in the world more globally, management of international partnership and lastly deleveraging of the group.

I can also mention the decision of the French safety authority to extend the lifespan of the Fessenheim power plant for 10 years. This decision, of course, independent of the safety audits and stress tests to be conducted after Fukushima reflects, nevertheless, the quality of EDF's work and achievements in terms of maintenance and safety, successes that many are attempting to minimize. Within 18 months, our group has gained in strength and consistency in all of these priorities we've actually acheived better than our expectations and hopefully, better than your expectations, even though, and I regret it, none of this is truly reflected in our share price. But we can still continue to hope.

Over the long-term, last May we announced that we wanted to increase our installed capacity to 200 gigawatts by 2020. A few words, being a reference benchmark operator in 2020, mean, of course, that we need to have an energy mix that will be competitive and diversified with projects that will enable us to reach this ambition of 200 gigawatt of raw capacity, up approximately 30% versus today. As I said, the 2020 energy mix in EDF will be broken down into 50% nuclear power, 25% fossil-fired and 25% hydropower, plus other renewable energy sources, which implies an ambitious development in these forms of energies. The group will thus to have a 75% CO2-free energy fleet and 50% internationally, which of course means that three-fourths of these new capacities will be built outside of France.

These developments will be based on new forms of contract-based-engineering, meaning that we will not necessarily have to hold 100% of the assets, management for third-party account, concessions or Winamp (21:35), investment of the IPP type. We will thus be able to limit our risk exposure while endorsing the full responsibility of the industrial and technological choices.

These projects of new capacities, well, you're familiar with them as we already mentioned them. Projects in construction account for approximately 8 gigawatts in addition, in nuclear power, the EPI in Flamanville, plus 2 EPIs in Taiwan and China, in fossil-fired, two CCGT's are being built in France are Blénod and Martigues, and one in the U.K. Other projects have been identified for approximately 34 gigawatts, such as the EPI in the U.K. and we could've also considered other hydro-power international projects based on the Nam Theun model.

The example of Nam Theun shows actually that the increase in the Group's installed capacity does not necessarily involve heavy investments in capital since we own today 40% of the company that owns the power plant, but we do have full industrial control, thus we estimate that 40 gigawatt of capacity for the group should be re commissioned that 2 reach the 200 gigawatt project in 2020.
We'll now give the floor to Thomas Piquemal for a detailed financial presentation.

Good morning, ladies and gentleman, I'll now give you a detailed explanation of our results for the first half of 2011, confirming our objectives for the current year and I will share with you our medium-term outlooks and the targets we have set for 2011, 2015. But before talking about the present and future, I suggest you should look back at the past. Just to pinpoint the presentation for 2010 based on IFRS 5 standards, we have the contribution of EnBW as an asset available for sale. In the reported results, we've the contribution of assets that we disposed of in 2010.

I'm referring to the British networks and the Eggborough power plant in the U.K., as well. A contribution which was reprocessed just as the contribution of RTE, which has now fully equity consolidated, reprocessed for the results of the first half of 2010, so as to propose a comparative basis, so that you can properly measure the operational performance of EDF in the first half of 2011.

The chairman gave you the main key figures, sales up, organic growth of 2.7%, EBITDA at 8616 million plus 6.2%, therefore on a like-for-like basis, as compared to the first half of 2010. The group share of net income multiplied by almost 2.4 on a like-for-like basis. Let me point out that last year, in the first half of 2010, we had recorded non-recurrent losses, losses in value on our American values almost €1 billion. Of course, we do not have this impact in the first half of 2011, we process for non-recurring items, and net income is up by plus 12.5% to €2,629 million.

The debt is below €30 billion, reduced as compared to figures in 31st of December 2010, reaching towards €9.2 billion, namely twice EBITDA. As I said, sales up by 2.7% plus €870 million in sales, thanks to a fine performance by France €651 million, plus €219 million, but this relation is due to the fact that revenue in the U.K. is down due to the drop in volume and very small margin in the B2B business.

EBITDA is up by 6.2%, they are truly driven by the performance in France plus 400 million EBITDA out of the total of 500 million organically. Internationally, all of our businesses are arising aside from Italy, which I will tell you more about in just a few moments.

EBITDA is up by 6.2%, amortizations are, more or less, stable as compared to the previous year. No losses in value, especially in the United States, so EBIT of 5,256 plus 30% almost 40% as compared to the previous year.

This slight improvement in our financial income done by 7.3% has enabled us, therefore, to have a significant improvement in the Group income of net – in a good share of net income, and the progress shown of net income excluding non-recurring items up by 12.5%.

Non-recurring items are kind of offset in this half, over a positive impact. We had the capital gains under this divestment of our German subsidiary €263 million. To the final – this operational was finalized in February. In view of this capital gain of €263 million, we had a loss of value internationally mainly in Italy, where we have a 50% share consolidated in our accounts for a total €170 million from Dalkia International; this is, although, non-recurring items giving us a total of minus €7.5 billion as compared to €1.3 billion last year.

Let me point that, on the other matter €151 million, we also accounted for, while even though it's very difficult for us to understand this, the consequences of the regulation published in the beginning of July, regarding the compensation of our competitors were tied down. It's very hard for us to understand and we're hoping to have clarifications on the French regulatory authorities during the second half of this year.

The volume performance by France plus 8.3% in organic growth is mainly driven by the increase in nuclear output generating €17 billion in excess nuclear offset, and the drop in hydro-power generation on also due to a major weather condition in the first half of 2011 compared to 2010. The – We also benefited from higher prices of the wholesale market and we're able to benefit from this, thanks to the excess nuclear output. So we can see the impact of choices made in terms of human resources as of the beginning of 2010 and the accelerated recruitment campaign.

Our perception of changes in EBITDA consist in looking at regulated activities, which now include mainly ErDF's; we're now consolidating RTE, which is under equity consolidation and non-regulated, meaning production and downstream and optimization. We can see that this offsets the drop in volume due to a mild of weather conditions in 2011 versus 2010, in the non-regulated sectors the progression is 10.8%, was significant in the unregulated sector and the lower section can reproduce the improvement in nuclear production plus 15.5%.

Whereas, the demand for end customers is down by 18.6 kilowatt hours, mainly due to mild weather conditions, 13 kilowatt hours less. We are able to sell more in the markets and therefore, as I said before, we're able to benefit from higher margins thanks to a positive price effect. Nuclear production has improved significantly, a constant progression every month. This chart shows the trends we have seen in 2010, where we had said that, as of May last year, that we had crossed a new threshold month-by-month.

Nuclear output has been rising plus 7.7% in total figures for the half year over 15 terawatt hours, in excess generated. All of this, due to the fact that shutdowns are must – are better controlled you can see here on this chart, in blue, which shows unplanned outages. Quarter after quarter they are dropping as compared to what we saw in 2010 and then it begins to improve our nuclear output target from between 411, 418 terawatt hours while maintaining our availability a target of 78.6%. In hydropower is quite different due to the hydrological conditions in the first half of 2011, very poor historically, as you can see in blue, and in 2010 in black.

You must have understood that, on this chart, where I'm talking about the red curve; for the first half of 2011. We did not continue it in July. Of course, we expect a slight improvement given the weather conditions in France today, but it won't really change much.

You lose nothing in terms of the current reservoirs, and must remain precautious when it comes to hydro-power output in the second half. And this is the gather that explains the fact that output is up by 35.2%, as compared to the first half of 2010, which is quite significant, of course, in terms of our results.

But you're able to offset this, thanks to nuclear output in particular. Nuclear output was almost rising sharply in the UK, explaining the fine performance of our British subsidiary plus 12% EBITDA and organic growth due to the fact that production was rising by 6.2 terawatt hours in that quarter, a half of which was achieved thanks to the fact that we had no generic problems just last year.

In this half, we were penalized by the shutdown of the Sizewell power plants which accounted for 3 terawatt hours that were lost. Electricity, you can see that nuclear production is rising. Sales in B2B declining, but these are selected choices made to preserve margins, down by 5 terawatt hours, all-in-all the terawatt has to – by less, under market, as you can see on the top left of the chart minus 10 terawatt hours. All of our international operations are improving, except in Italy. These figures, as presented here, are down by 40%, including EDISON in EBITDA that report us straight away that we did not account for the very positive impact for EDISON of the renegotiation of gas supply contracts with gas farm.

Contract signed about one week ago, and which made it possible for EDISON to record extra gains at this period. We did not account for it due to the time on EBITDA agenda and that for the Group is immaterial even though it is important for EDISON. With that, we have to have €56 million on this chart. We will do that of course through the second half. Aside from this good news, which enabled EDISON to confirm its objective of 900 million in EBITDA for 2011, you can see that performance is dropping, showing difficulties on the Italian markets, especially shrinking margins in the field of electricity and gas.

Internationally, all businesses are improving except in the United States because they're right now putting new nuclear projects. As a charge EBITDA is up by 10% driven by the very high performance of our subsidiary in Belgium. Amongst our other businesses, EDF Energies Nouvelles reported its results yesterday. The trading activity is up in trading, up by about – well, up by 5.7% exactly, after the start of the year that was difficult with a certain level of volatility. In the year for energy, these figures are significant, plus 18%, even though we expect more disposals in the second half. So the – progression for the year will be even more significant.

Free cash flow is positive, plus €300 million, to be compared to the first half of 2010 at 1.3 billion, which included the first payout for 1.7 billion, because we process for that. You can see that we have improved as compared to the first half of 2010. And all this was achieved even though the insufficient compensation with respect to the SPE affected this quarter for about €500 million in our accounts, as in the previous period, in terms of our working capital requirements.

Positive free cash flow – positive, therefore, even though we are continuing to invest significantly. Our CapEx up by 2.7%, gross CapEx, as compared to the previous year with the same breakdown as what I presented at the general meeting; of course, taken into account the deconsolidation of RTE, about 30% of regulated business, the remaining 50/50 between maintenance and development. Net financial debt is dropping sharply, €29.2 billion versus €34.4 million at the end of December 2010, thanks to the collection of assets from disposal of EnBW €7.1 billion for the balance of securities and the deconsolidation of the debt. This figure does not include an uncommitted amount. So, this is merely the impact with respect to our debt; a positive impact, €300 million. €200 million for the period, for dedicated assets, less than in the previous period.

Indeed, we are benefiting from the allocation of RTE securities, 50% is dedicated assets, allowing us to build up for a longer period the – our dedicated assets. We paid out the remaining dividends, €1.2 billion, in cash and we carried out the acquisition of EDF Energies Nouvelles minorities' asset sales, because after this offering we will be on a 6.7% of capital at EDF Energies Nouvelles, starting with down 50% with the compulsory on withdrawal.

And as of Octeville, who we'll fully -own the subsidiary. There was one section that was in cash, €40 per cash – per security, and one in securities, followed by the intensification of the EDF share buyback program, selected to cancel the dilutive effect lent to the portion in cash. So, if we were to add up the cash portion, the share buyback program, as well as the mandatory squeeze-up in the coming weeks, the total cost for EDF in cash would be €1.5 billion. Meaning that cost price per security would be €38, meaning a premium of 50% on the stock market price of EDF EN.

Now, all of this allows us to confirm our objectives of 2011. EBITDA will rise by 4% to 6%, before taking into account the unexplained compensation due to TaRTAM. Once again, we hope we'll get clarifications on this on the second half. We do not really understand the TaRTAM cost, which is clearly the link to the factor on competitors did not cover themselves, so hedge on the market as we did at the end of the year.

But the TaRTAM will disappear as of the 1 of July, adding to the non-recurring aspect of this portion. So, we expect therefore an EBITDA growth of between 4% and 6%, on the financial debt of EBITDA ratio I'll say 2% to 2.2% at the beginning of the year; including the impact of energy in Nouvelles, so we'll have 2.1% to 2.3%, with our objective we maintained of a dividend that will be at least stable to be paid out for 2011.

In the introduction I pointed out, I see this opportunity to share with you our medium-term outlooks and our objectives of 2015. Our objective is to enable profitable growth for EDF, based on six key drivers. First of all, anticipating on the renewal of scales to be able to reveal with the significant churns due to retirements over the next coming years. The second driver – I'll cover all the drivers, one after the other – the second driver consists in capitalizing on know-how in R&D, as well as in contractual engineering. Thirdly, investing in the power generation fleet at the network as it'll show that these investments create value even though we are talking about maintenance.

Fourthly, continue the Group's selective development, more selectively. As the Chairman mentioned in his introduction, from now on we have investment criteria that are far more selective than in the past. Fifthly, reinforce financial solidity; and lastly, step up, transformation and synergy effortswith greater synergies within the group and more and more transformation.

The first driver is a key challenge for our group, renewing skills, the need for us to anticipate. Let me give you one example in the field of production and engineering in France, from 2011 to 2015 there were more than 10,000 new hires, a net increase of our stock by 2,300, net of retirements. This is just one example, I could have taken many others, and of course we could spend much more time on this.

But once again, I must point out that it is our key growth driver for profitable growth and it is a huge challenge for our group to enable skills to be renewed and the development of engineering capacities at the time when we will be conducting major growth projects abroad, in particular, and to supports the capitalization – upon know-how abroad in particular. No need to invest to grow, to grow competitively. Growth will be based on an R&D effort that will be intensified. Our R&D budget is now €500 million per year, more or less, and we have 2,000 people working in our key research areas with three major areas for R&D.

First, the energy mix, carbon-free that is a nuclear, with one example, amongst many others, with respect to ageing materials and research. In renewable energies, there is one example amongst many others; there is research for example on new generation photovoltaic technologies to make them more competitive. The second key area for R&D refers to networks at the time when we decentralized energy. There is more-and-more of a need for renewable energies. Smart meters, of course, in my frontiers the smart-grids in which we are investing significantly, more particularly in research and development.

The third is main area is in energy demand management, energy efficiency and also the issue of the sustainable city to capitalize in know-how also means contractual engineering and partnerships. No need to invest to develop the group abroad by capitalizing on its know-how. A few example of this contract engineering and partnerships that Henri Proglio mentioned earlier in his presentation, in the field of delegated network management for instance with the MRSK agreement in Russia. We have a team who has been put in charge of improving the network efficiency and that's an excellent example of what could be done in terms of network improvement and I am sure there will be many more over the coming months.

For example, second example in the U.S., where we manage 15 gig watts for a third party account in field of optimization and trading. This is a key success of EDFs trade in North America, that should continue expanding as well. In the U.S., we've also managed wind farms for a third party account, 4.8 gig watt are managed by enXco subsidiaries in the U.S.

There again, we want to capitalize on the Group's expertise, and know how with that additional financial investments. And naturally, they will be project-by-project partnerships, the latest example being the Nam Theun 2 partnership in Laos that Proglio mentioned. I said one of our key drivers for medium-term growth is to continue investing in our nuclear generation and in our – in the power plants and the networks.

In France, our target is to multiply by two the maintenance CapEx over the period 2011, 2015, in all areas. 10 year inspection shut-downs and inspection visits what you know more – the more we go with time, we're not looking – looking at the 13,00 megawatt plans than the 11,00 that we're doing.
We're also continue investing and replacing major components, as well the power plants operation.

All of these investments, as I said, create value. First of all, because it enable us to anticipate on the extended live stand. As long as you change major components, you don't do that for just four or five years, you do it for several tens of years.

Secondly, over the period, this type of capital investiture – expenditures up to 2015, 2011 – '18 will enable us to increase by approximately 400 megawatt hour capacity. This is the case for the 900 megawatt unit when we exchanged the (45:40) that increased the generation output. Lastly, this CapEx are into the fact that we're intensifying preventive maintenance with the AP-913 plant, thereby improving the availability of our power plants and thereby a better plan, the maintenance shut down or anticipate on any possible failure.

All of that while benefiting the – from the best safety standards and secure extensions beyond the 40 years last plan. We also continue on our selective developments, every year we develop €1.4 billion to development CapEx and we will go from 4 to approximately 5 by 2015, due in particular to the CapEx power plant in nuclear power in the U.K.

Our investment criteria are extremely strict measured in terms of value creation. 300 basis points versus the watt. In the other words, 300 basis points above the weighted average cost of capital, much stricter criteria above 150 basis points, so that we can now optimize the various management and operational support from the various corporate function.

In view of this investment in maintenance, in development, in maintenance and network and plants, we plan to go from approximately €11 billion up to, let say, around €14 billion on average, while preserving the financial standards of our group.

Thanks to control of our debt, that should remain below 2.5 billion, and thanks also and mostly to the high visibility of our cash flows. In our cash flows, we have regulated activities. We also have renewable businesses that are back to electricity – long-term electricity sales contracts. We also benefit from the reforms on the French and British market, so that we can derisk if you will our investment, particularly restated by the new British government decision. That goes beyond the 2015 timescale, since you know the new schedule – reviewed schedule to now target 2016. But the full year should be 12 or 13 terawatt hour in terms of output from the EPR Flamanville. So, you can do the calculations on your own.
Another question on the results of EDF Trading.
You will find more details on the financial results of EDF Trading, and I suggest that you refer to the annexes to the financial accounts.

Question from the floor, Reuters. Recently, Arriba announced that the cost of the additional safety measures for nuclear power plant could reach up to €100 or €200 million per plant. Does that estimate look adequate to you?

Second question, regarding the EPR at Poly or whether the project, do you think that project is still needed? Can you tell us how far you are in terms of considerations and any timescale or calendar on this project?

Regarding the announcement made by Arriba, well, Arriba that's quite natural for any kind of industrialist. Arriba is showing proposals, saying what would I intend to do if that type of work in the context of this or that. All I can say is that, of course, this does not commit us in any way. And even though I can understand that kind of approach.

But secondly, our estimates are done quite naturally by taking into account our own estimates on investments made in terms of maintenance and extension of the lifespan of power plant. We can't break down whatever is linked to safety measures specifically in the post-Fukushima area.

It is, of course, our obligation to make sure that our investment guarantee the safety regardless of what has happened, and that is – these are the assumptions used to calculate our figures. As for orientations to be taken by the ASN or the French Nuclear Safety Authority, let's wait and see what they say.

Our responsibility to a nuclear barge is like in any other areas. And wherever we are, France, U.K., or elsewhere, is to provide the safety and security of our facilities overtime sustainable and under the strictest standards. And that is why we have provisioned the necessary investments in our accounts. That is basically the only answer I can give you.

Regarding the Poly EPR project, obviously, it's ongoing, as you know there are number of enquiries, investigations going on, so let's just wait and see for that procedure to go ahead without trying to anticipate anything for the future. These producers are necessary, permitting process is underway at the poly and everything is going along with the plans.
Question from the internet. Regarding the CapEx outlook after 2015?

Little bit difficult, because we start at 2015 naturally CapEx effects will continue beyond that and then more we go over time, the more there will be need to – for replacement and maintenance and in order to extent the large spend, but for today we have used 2015 to calculate our figures.

Question from the floor. Question is linked to the operational performance program? In the first half year we've had – we've seen a good improvement of operational performance, is this sustainable to what extent can we expected to be sustained?

There seems to be an increased in unplanned outages, so we in order to understand the level for next year, when we look at the 10-year inspection reviews, we could expect a net positive boost effect as compared with 2011. Since you will have less of this 10 years maintenance shutdowns, perhaps 1%or 2% might be the positive impact?

Yes, this year we'll have nine inspection visit against five last year, next year we will have six of this 10 years inspections. And because this year we'll have four more than last year it's costing us 1.4 – 1.5 points in KD factor. Last year, we'll have more normal number of 10-year inspections, so mechanically we should be able to benefit from this additional availability.

Also means that while keeping an objective of stable KD factor at 78.5 similar to last year, it means that the intrinsic availability of the facilities has actually improved 1.5 points in 2011, with better management of the shutdowns and replacement of the major components. And you're right in 2012, mechanically, we can expect 1.5 additional points in availability simply since, because there will be less 10-year inspection shutdowns.

Question from Bloomberg. First question addresses the U.K. do you think that you will need to have now support of subsidies from the government, and do you have increase cost for the EPR that you have experience in Flamanville for instance?
The second question, well, why don't you reply to this first question, because I have lost my train of thought on the floor?

Reform of electricity market in the U.K. now, the principle of it is not to have the customer bare the responsibility of the operator and builder in terms of debt lines and cost. The purpose is to guarantee a certain stability and predictability both for investors and for customers on the revenue linked to the electricity output. That is the purpose of that reform.

So, our responsibility is to control our cost, to commit ourselves, to make sure that we can secure revenues to have to keep good control over the construction cost as well; and in return the British Government will look at in – at the different contracts and then the British Government based on carbon prices and cost prices and so on.

We'll make a commitment on a straight price – over is – length of time could be 15 to 20 years. So the mechanism planned by the British Government is intended to provide stability on prices, both for investor – the investors and the customer, it's a win-win mechanism really. It is not a mechanism that would enable us to pass through to the client any surplus cost in terms of the construction cost toward others.
My second question regards the Atnea projects. Do you think that it will see the light of day and do you think that it is really adapted to the 1,000 megawatt reactor as you have at EDF?
No. Reactors are 1,000 megawatt EPAs, EPRs, CPR 1000. I mean, if we were starting to detail all these different reactors...

Well, Atnea is a process that was initiated by Arriba, has the merit of existing. Now, our corporation was Arriba is strengthening and among other, we ambitioned to add or to integrate into our review, 81,000 megawatt reactor that would be adapted to the needs of customers that are geographically differentiated and that will demand technologies that are suitable for their own needs, with industrial partnerships that are also diversified and we have taken a clear orientation towards these technologies. Now recently, together with Arriba and as in (110:53) probably will tell you more about it. But we had discussion with Arriba regarding projects that are currently being investigated.

I can not give you any final judgment on this or that type of reactor model. We are not builders of reactors, we are operators. We're very much aware as – of our responsibility as a leader of this nuclear French industry, and we are working in close cooperation with all partners in the industry to enable them to secure the best opportunities for development throughout the world. And that is a topic that is currently being investigated and discussed. And I can not discuss it from an industrial set perspective about this or that type of reactor. It depends on the typology of the clients as much as the typology of the industry operator's concerned.

I am from ENSA. Two questions of Edison. You spoke about the public authorities that planned the first agreement. Do you think that could happen again or can you make sure that it won't take place? Secondly, would you be ready to let an Italian takeover the Chairman ship of Edison, of what argent?

Your second question is quite surprising. I don't see why we would forbid an Italian to be the Chairman of Edison. Easily that person was confident. The first question is not up to me to make any prognosis, like to guess what the public authorities will plan to do their contracts that are – have been signed and so far, but they are all well intentioned.

But once again, I won't speak for the Italian public authorities is for the public authorities to speak for themselves and you will certainly understand that it give the agitation at present on the markets; the landscape, is a bit agitated today around the world to be it in Europe or even in Italy. And amongst the priorities this has not been viewed as – been a greater priority than others.

Well, once again, we have made proposals, we proposed an industrial action plan in the best interest of Edison, Italy. That's all I can say. And they will abstain from any comments on the reactions of the Italian Public Authorities are waiting for them, to make their announcements. We have heard comments by members of government. We seemed to have understood or taken on Board our proposals in their studies.
